Dear Amy Harding:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Supervision.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12505
Section • (2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
Description supervision:
• (a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least
once each month at a youth's place of residence.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency did not make face-to-face contact with the youth in his IL
placement between October 2023 and March 2024.
Investigation The Complainant was anonymous and unable to be
interviewed.
DHHS Foster Care Supervisor 2 (FC Supervisor 2) was
interviewed via video conference on April 1, 2024. She stated
Holy Cross contacted her to discuss transfer of Youth A’s case
due to his age and court jurisdiction recently ending. The email
was sent from DHHS FC Supervisor 2 on September 7, 2023, and
indicated Youth A turned 19 and based on policy the agency is not
able to maintain the case and asked how they would like to
proceed. On September 18, 2023, DHHS FC Supervisor 2
indicated her office agreed Youth A was not ready to have his
case closed and asked if Youth A would be able to transition to
Young Adult Voluntary Foster Care (YAVFC).
DHHS FC Supervisor 2 clarified their office did not at any point
indicate they would be unwilling to accept the case transfer. A
case transfer meeting was held in November 2023 when it was
decided the case would transfer back to Department of Health and
Human Services (DHHS). Prior to transferring the case, the
expectation was the case would be up to date prior to case
transfer acceptance. The case file had two late service plans that
needed to be completed and DHHS FC Supervisor 2 requested
multiple times that face-to-face contact be made with Youth A to
ensure his safety and wellbeing since it was noticed that contact
had not been made with him in a few months and there were no
social work contacts that indicated any attempts to verify wellbeing
had been made. She reminded the agency they are responsible
for case management responsibilities up until the case is
2

transferred. There was email correspondence between the two
agencies for a few months while the case work was caught up.
DHHS FC Supervisor 2 stated her office took the stance that it
would be appropriate to close Youth A’s case if they are unable to
locate him and he is not willing to engage in services. He could
come back and participate in YAVFC if he chooses to do so later.
Foster Care Worker 1 (FCW1) was interviewed via telephone
on April 2, 2024. She stated she was Youth A’s assigned
caseworker until she left for maternity leave on October 13, 2023.
She returned from leave in January and was reassigned to Youth
A’s case on February 22, 2024. Youth A contacted her on October
25, 2023, while she was on leave and inquired who his
caseworker was. FCW1 contacted FCW2 and informed her Youth
A had contacted her but neither one reached out to him. She
stated there were no documented attempts in the case file.
Upon her return she was advised face-to-face contact had not
been made with Youth A since she left and to attempt face-to-face
contact with him. FCW1 was asked about Youth A’s level of
participation, and she stated during the course of his independent
living placement he was not participating in work, school or any
services that would promote independence.
Foster Care Worker 2 (FCW2) was interviewed via telephone
on April 2, 2024. She stated she reached out to the DHHS office
that oversees Youth A’s case prior to him turning 19 to advise of
his upcoming birthday at the beginning of September 2023 and of
the court hearing that was scheduled at the end of September
2023. Upon receiving the court order that indicated court
jurisdiction had closed, FCW2 contacted the DHHS office again
and it was agreed Holy Cross would complete some case
management items prior to transferring the case to DHHS.
A case transfer conference was held in December 2023. FCW2
stated DHHS did not at any point refuse to accept case transfer
however, during the meeting DHHS insisted the case service
plans were current and requested Holy Cross make face-to-face
contact with Youth A to verify his wellbeing prior to accepting case
transfer. FCW2 stated multiple attempts were made to contact
Youth A but were unsuccessful. The attempts included
unannounced visits, driving around the location Youth A resides,
and mailing a letter to his PO Box. FCW1 returned from maternity
leave at the end of February 2024 and was able to make face-to-
face with Youth A.
3

During his independent living (IL) case, Youth A was not
participating in work, school or any services. The agency hoped
Youth A would be able to participate in YAVFC but due to his
refusal to participate in work, school and services he would not be
eligible.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on April 2, 2024. He
stated FCW1 was on maternity leave from October 2023 through
March 2024. During that timeframe his case was reassigned to
someone else and no one from the agency ever reached out to
him. Youth A stated he had a government issued phone until the
end of October and the agency could have contacted him via
email or through mail. Youth A clarified that FCW 1 had assisted
him with obtaining a PO Box prior to going on maternity leave. He
stated he has been residing in the same location since prior to
October and he is not aware of any attempts to complete a home
visit with him. Youth A stated he tried to locate a phone number
for someone at Holy Cross but was not able to find one. He was
hopeful someone at the agency could assist him with some of the
things FCW1 had been working with him on prior to going on
maternity leave.
PAFC Foster Care Supervisor 1 (FC Supervisor 1) was
interviewed via telephone on April 4, 2024. She stated Youth A
turned 19 at the beginning of September 2023 and there was a
court hearing on September 22, 2023. During the court hearing
the court terminated jurisdiction. Upon receiving the signed court
order a week or so later, the agency contacted the DHHS office to
inform them Michigan Children’s Institute (MCI) and court
jurisdiction is closed, and the agency intended on working on
closing the case and routing to DHHS. At that point, DHHS
inquired if Youth A was ready for closure and whether or not the
case was able to remain open. PAFC FC Supervisor 1 stated she
informed DHHS Youth A was not eligible for YAVFC due to not
participating in any services, employment, or school. DHHS
indicated Youth A’s case should remain open. PAFC FC
Supervisor 1 stated there were discussions regarding whether or
not the agency could maintain case management and it was
determined Private Agency Foster Care (PAFC) are not able to
keep cases when youth turn 19. She stated a case transfer was
held at the beginning of December 2023; however, it took over a
month to schedule that.
PAFC FC Supervisor 1 stated the agency was transparent about
the fact they had not made face-to-face contact with Youth A since
court jurisdiction closed. In January 2024, the agency notified
4

DHHS the case was ready to be transferred. At that point, DHHS
requested face-to-face contact be made with Youth A. She stated
there were attempts in January, February and March to make
contact with Youth A but were unsuccessful. She didn’t specify the
number of attempts. The agency is reporting more attempts than
are documented in the case. In March, PAFC FC Supervisor 1
contacted DHHS and indicated the case needed to be transferred.
DHHS at that point, indicated they supported case closure due to
Youth A’s nonparticipation in services, employment and school
and back dated case closure to the date the court order was
received in September 2023.
Documents reviewed:
• September 22, 2023, court order. Court jurisdiction is
terminated due to Youth A turning 19.
• Youth A’s MISCAWIS file: social work contacts document
successful face-to-face with Youth A on September 29,
2023, October 6, 2023, and March 25, 2024. Unsuccessful
face-to-face contact with Youth A on March 1, 2024. All
contacts completed by FCW1. There are no social work
contacts that document anyone from Holy Cross attempted
to contact Youth A between October 6, 2023, and February
23, 2024, when FCW1 attempted to call him on his
girlfriend’s phone.
• Address listed in MISACWIS is Youth A’s PO Box.
• Email dated October 26, 2023, from DHHS FC Supervisor
2 to Holy Cross: “I had been in contact with FCW2 about
this. I had inquired about the youth’s permanency goal
status and whether he has an identified a supportive adult.
As we would want to ensure he is set up for success with
supports prior to closing his foster care program type”.
• Email dated December 28, 2023, from DHHS FC
Supervisor 2 to Holy Cross: “Checking back in on the
completion of the USP for Youth A due 12/23/2023. This
report is now overdue, and we remain unable to transfer FC
case management to our agency until it has been
completed. I also see there have been no social work
contacts entered since October. Can you please verify that
you continue to maintain contact with the youth and are
doing monthly face to face visits with him per policy? Social
work contacts will also need to be updated prior to the case
transfer.
• Email dated February 20, 2024, from Program Manager of
DHHS FC Supervisor 2: “On 2/6 PAFC FC Supervisor 1
indicated the case was being assigned back to the worker
and efforts would be made to get in touch with Youth
5

A. We have requested that face to face contact was made
to ensure safety and well-being, confirm placement and IL
status, and his needs being met.
• Email dated March 5, 2024, from PAFC FC Supervisor 1: “I
wanted to provide an update and hopefully get some clarity
on how you would like to proceed. We have attempted to
contact and/or engage with Youth A multiple times.
• Several drop in at his LKA.
• Drop ins at his LKA girlfriends’ home - no response.
• Drop ins at his know best friend's home - no response.
• Drove around Belding and checked known spots he
would frequent.
• Checked the library that he would often frequent.
His primary phone is no longer in service, other phone
numbers have been called and texted, just in case he
switched back. We also sent a letter to his P.O. box”.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance. Based on interviews,
email documentation and Youth A’s MISACWIS case file the
agency did not make any attempt to contact Youth A between
October 6, 2023, and February 23, 2024, despite repeated
requests over several weeks for the agency to verify his safety
and wellbeing.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Development of service plans
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418
Section • (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
Description child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Agency did not complete service plans on Youth A's case timely.
Investigation The Complainant was anonymous so no interview could be
conducted.
DHHS Foster Care Supervisor 2 (FC Supervisor 2) was
interviewed via video conference on April 1, 2024. She stated
6

Holy Cross contacted her to discuss transfer of Youth A’s case
due to his age and court jurisdiction recently ending.
FC Supervisor 2 clarified their office did not at any point indicate
they would be unwilling to accept the case transfer. A case
transfer meeting was held in November 2023 where it was
decided the case would transfer back to DHHS. Prior to
transferring the case, the expectation was the case would be up to
date prior to case transfer acceptance. The case file had two late
service plans that needed to be completed and FC Supervisor 2
requested multiple times that face-to-face contact be made with
Youth A to ensure his safety and wellbeing since it was noticed
that contact had not been made with him in a few months and
there were no social work contacts that indicated any attempts to
verify wellbeing had been made. She reminded the agency they
are responsible for case management responsibilities up until the
case has transferred.
Foster care worker 2 (FCW2) was interviewed via telephone
on April 2, 2024. She stated she reached out to the DHHS office
that oversees Youth A’s case prior to him turning 19 to advise of
his upcoming birthday at the beginning of September and court
hearing that was scheduled at the end of September. Upon
receiving the court order that indicated court jurisdiction had
closed, FCW2 contacted the DHHS office again and it was agreed
Holy Cross would complete some case management items prior to
transferring the case to DHHS. FCW2 stated the agency recently
terminated the foster care supervisor who was previously
assigned. She stated she was not aware of the overdue reports
until it was discussed at the case transfer meeting. She clarified
one report was significantly overdue and another report would be
due soon.
PAFC Foster Care Supervisor 1 (FC Supervisor 1) was
interviewed via telephone on April 4, 2024. She stated Youth A
turned 19 at the beginning of September 2023 and there was a
court hearing on September 22, 2023. During the court hearing
the court terminated jurisdiction. Upon receiving the signed court
order a week or so later, the agency contacted the DHHS office to
inform them MCI and court jurisdiction is closed, and the agency
intended on working on closing the case and routing to DHHS. At
that point, DHHS inquired if Youth A was ready for closure and
whether or not the case was able to remain open. FC Supervisor 1
stated she informed DHHS Youth A was not eligible for YAVFC
due to not participating in any services, employment, or school.
DHHS indicated Youth A’s case should remain open.
7

FC Supervisor 1 stated the agency had acknowledged there were
case management items that needed to be completed prior to
transfer such as overdue service plans. She stated the agency
has struggled with staffing issues and the overdue service plans
were completed as quickly as possible.
Documents reviewed:
• USP due September 24, 2023, submitted on December 7,
2023.
• USP due December 23, 2023, submitted on January 7,
2024.
• Emailed dated December 1, 2023, from FC Supervisor 2:
“This youth remained in foster care after the Court
terminated jurisdiction with an open foster care program
type. Therefore, Holy Cross remains responsible for
managing this case until it transfers back to our agency. I
was not on the meeting this morning, but my understanding
is that FCW2 is going to have the reports updated as soon
as possible so that this can transfer to us”.
• Email dated December 28, 2023, from FC Supervisor 2 to
Holy Cross: “Checking back in on the completion of the
USP for Youth A due 12/23/2023. This report is now
overdue, and we remain unable to transfer FC case
management to our agency until it has been completed”.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance. Based upon interviews,
email documentation and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case the
agency did not complete September 24, 2023, USP and
December 23, 2023, USP timely.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2/12/2024 Interim, CAP approved 3/28/2024
1/26/2023 Renewal, CAP approved 2/15/2023
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
